 POLAND - POWER TRANSMISSION PROJECT Loan and Project Summary Borrower: The Polish Power Grid Company (PPGC). Guarantor: Republic of Poland. Amount: US$160 million equivalent. Terms: Currency pool loan with a maturity of 17 years, including four years of grace, at the Bank's standard variable interest rate. Project Objectives: The project's objectives are to: (a) improve the reliability of the existing high voltage grid through rehabilitation and reinforcement; (b) enhance security of power supply in Poland by interconnecting the Polish power grid with that of Western Europe, thus improving Poland's power trade and wheeling capability; (c) improve the network's operational performance and control through transmission loss reduction and improved dispatching, thereby enhancing energy conservation and efficiency; (d) reduce environmental pollution; and (e) enhance PPGC's institutional capabilities. The project takes place within the framework of the continuing policy dialogue with the Government regarding the energy sector restructuring program, particularly as it relates to achieving further improvement in energy pricing policies and introduction of a sound regulatory framework. Proj ect Description: The project comprises: (a) investments in rehabilitation and upgrading of key substations and modernization of high voltage transmission lines; and (b) technical assistance to PPGC. Benefits: The project has an estimated rate of return of 21%, using PPGC's incremental transmission revenues as a proxy for the economic benefits. In qualitative terms benefits can be described as follows: (a) enhanced reliability of the transmission system; (b) reduced transmission losses and operation and maintenance costs; (c) increased income from power wheeling and exports; and (d) reduced environmental pollution. Risks: The main risk associated with the project is the possibility of delayed increases in electricity prices. Such a delay could negatively affect PPGC's internal cash flow, needed for further system improvements. However, this risk is manageable, given the Government's commitment to energy price reform as demonstrated by energy pricing adjustments undertaken since 1990 and its efforts to introduce an energy
 - viii - regulatory framework, combined with recent favorable changes in asset revaluation and depreciation policy. Furthermore, the project's cash flow is based on the conservative assumption of zero price increases in real terms over the medium term. Price decreases in real terms are highly unlikely over the medium term and would, in first instance, only lead to a slowing down of the pace of investments and their associated benefits. The risk of procurement and implementation delays are manageable because: (a) PPGC has set up a procurement unit that has received training from specialized Bank staff; (b) adequate staff has been allocated to the different project management activities. This staff could, if necessary, be assisted by consultants who would provide both functional support as well as training under the project's technical assistance component; and (c) tight reporting schedules on procurement and implementation progress during supervision. Poverty Category: Not applicable.

 PART I - INTRODUCTION 1. In the context of its Economic Transformation Program (1990), the Polish Government sought Bank cooperation to develop an energy policy that would enhance efficiency and increase competition in the sector. Implementation started with the Energy Resource Development Project (Loan 3215-POL), followed by the Heat Supply Restructuring and Conservation Project (Loans 3377/83-POL) which included a Sector Adjustment Loan (SECAL; Loan 3377-POL); and the Katowice Heat Supply and Conservation Project (Loan 3809-POL). The SECAL supported a comprehensive energy sector restructuring program, including price liberalization, commercialization and privatization of energy sector enterprises where possible, and introduction of a sound and consistent regulatory framework. 2. The Polish Power Grid Company (PPGC) was the first enterprise in the electric power sector to become a joint stock company. The company is fully owned by the Treasury, represented by the Ministry of Industry and Trade. PPGC plays a pivotal role in the sector because of its dispatching and system planning functions and because it has taken a lead role in defining, and seeking to resolve, the issues related to the profound restructuring that the sector is going through. The Government asked the Bank to assist in the preparation of a high priority power transmission project to improve the reliability of the power grid and reduce transmission losses, as well as to cooperate in sector investment planning and in issues related to the proper functioning of PPGC in a restructured power sector. 3. Poland is strategically located between Eastern and Western Europe. Because of its geographical position, the efficient interconnection and future development of the European power network depends to a large extent on Poland's ability to upgrade its power system in order to fully meet the performance and interconnection criteria of the (West European) Union for the Coordination of Production and Transmission of Electricity (UCPTE). 4. However, a satisfactory performance of the Polish power system within the European context can only be achieved by first ensuring a reliable domestic system. The proposed US$276 million project aims to help achieve that goal. The amount of the proposed Bank loan is US$160 million, covering 95% of the foreign exchange costs of the project, or 58% of the total project costs after import duties and taxes. The Bank loan would also cover interest during construction on the loan amount given the length of the project's construction period and the fact that the Bank loan would constitute only a modest portion of PPGC's overall investment program financing requirements. The remaining project costs would be funded by PPGC from net internal cash generation. 5. Documents and detailed information concerning the sector and the project are available in the Project File (Annex 1-1).
 PART 11 - THE SECTOR A. Economic Significance 6. The energy sector is one of the largest sectors of the Polish economy. Energy intensity is estimated to be about two times as high as in European OECD countries on a purchasing power of currency estimate of GDP basis, although per capita energy consumption is at about 60% of the OECD level. New energy pricing policies, introduced starting in 1990, have led to price levels and structures that are now beginning to provide incentives for energy conservation and efficiency. The Government is no longer providing funding for energy sector investments. The more efficient energy enterprises are beginning to have cash flows which allow them to self-finance minor investments. Government subsidies for energy production are now only provided to a small number of coal mines, while subsidies for household consumption of heat have been reduced from 78% in 1991 to about 10% at the beginning of 1995. The fiscal impact of these policies has been a dramatic reduction in energy sector outlays in the Government budget. 7. Poland's energy sector consists of five subsectors: two energy producing subsectors (hard coal/lignite and oil/gas), two energy conversion subsectors (electric power and district heating), and one energy processing subsector (oil refining). Together, they account for about 10% of the country's total investments. The energy sector accounts for about 8% of GDP and directly employs 4% of the working population. 8. Energy consumption in Poland decreased substantially as the economy experienced a sharp decline starting in 1990 while energy prices were being increased significantly. Industrial energy consumption declined by 31% through 1992 primarily due to the contraction in output in many industrial sectors and closure or downsizing of several major energy-intensive industries. Residential energy consumption decreased by 14% because of a considerable reduction in real household incomes and proportionally larger increases in residential energy prices. Corresponding to this, domestic energy production dropped by 20% for coal and 25% for natural gas. Coal exports decreased by almost one third. Energy imports (mainly oil and natural gas) also decreased considerably due to the overall decline in domestic energy consumption. As energy prices are moving towards economic levels, energy consumption patterns are changing: the share of coal, while still dominant, is declining in final consumption, and the share of oil and gas is increasing. This process would accelerate when the current supply constraints on natural gas decrease (para. 9). Details on energy production and consumption are in Annex 2-1. 9. The most crucial issue in energy trade is Poland's exclusive dependence on Russia (via the Ukraine) for all its gas imports. Poland is concerned that the economic and political situation there, and its potential impact on gas production and transmission, could interrupt supplies. Hence, Poland is actively examining alternative gas supply options such as supplies coming via a new pipeline through Belarus, the Britannia field in the North Sea, or supplies from Norway. These new supplies, however, are likely to be much more expensive than the price of gas currently supplied by Russia (although that price is likely to be revised upwards as well). The Government and the Bank have an ongoing
 - 3 - dialogue regarding the various gas import proposals and the guarantee issues related to take-or-pay contracts. B. Sector Restructuring a. Development Policy 10. Under the energy SECAL (Loan 3377-POL) of the Heat Supply Restructuring and Conservation Project, the Government undertook to implement a comprehensive energy sector restructuring program. Major changes have been and are being implemented in the energy sector in order to make it more competitive and viable. Firstly, most subsectors have been demonopolized and restructured. Secondly, many of the state-owned enterprises have been converted into joint stock or limited liability companies. Privatization of selected companies would follow as soon as possible, but the speed of the process depends on a number of factors (e.g., political will, allowed return on equity, etc.). Thirdly, energy prices have been adjusted considerably. Fourthly, a new Energy Law will be introduced which would, inter alia, put an appropriate regulatory framework into place and create an Energy Regulatory Agency. The regulatory framework would aim to enhance competition, allow open access to new entrants, protect consumers and avoid distortions in investment decisions between "network" fuels (district heat, gas and electric power). Good progress was made under the SECAL in implementing this energy sector restructuring program. However, continued implementation of the Government's energy sector strategy is important, inter alia, in order to enable private sector participation in development of the energy sector. Further progress needs to be made in adjusting energy prices towards economic levels and in introducing the new regulatory framework, and the Bank is continuing its dialogue with the Government on these issues (paras. 14-15). b. DemonoRolization. Commercialization and Restructuring 11. A February 1993 law transferred the responsibility for commercialization of the power and coal sectors to the Ministry of Industry. Sixty three coal mines have been grouped into seven commercialized multi-mine companies and three commercialized single-mine companies. A closure program for 8 out of the total of 71 mines has been initiated, and part or all of 4-5 other mines is expected to be slated for closure. The power sector has been demonopolized into separate transmission, generation and distribution companies. The transmission company (the Polish Power Grid Company - PPGC), the 33 distribution companies and three out of 34 generating plants have been commercialized. The remaining 31 generation enterprises would be commercialized after their merger into a small number of competitive generating companies has taken place. The Polish Oil and Gas Company, the last remaining monopoly, would be commercialized by the end of 1995, to be followed by separation of the service companies. To enhance competition, the first exploration and production licenses were awarded (to AMOCO and British Gas). However, some contractual issues still need to be resolved before exploration and production will start in earnest. Licensing rounds for other acreage and for coal-bed methane exploration and production took place in October 1992 and contracts were signed by AMOCO (IFC made a US$8.7 million equity investment in an AMOCO-operated coalbed methane project) and McCormick. In the district heating sector, significant restructuring and commercialization is underway with a new emphasis on network efficiency improvements, energy
 - 4 - conservation, cost reduction and competitiveness with other heat sources. About 100 out of 500 DHEs have been commercialized, including those of Gdansk, Gdynia and Krakow, all Borrowers under the Bank's Heat Supply Restructuring and Conservation Project. Those enterprises have started to spin off service companies which, in several instances, have been privatized. Six small DHEs have been privatized, which makes the district heating sector the first energy sector in Poland where actual privatization of operating companies took place. However, it is unlikely that privatization of larger energy enterprises, such as electricity generating plants,will occur in the near future. Finally, in the petroleum sector all activities (refining, transmission and distribution) are generally still in the hands of State-Owned Enterprises (SOEs), although there are some joint ventures and fully independent companies on the distribution end. The Government is in the process of defining its position with regard to the future ownership structure of the petroleum sector. c. Energy Pricing 12. Energy price reform has made major progress since 1990. Although significant further adjustments remain necessary for prices to reach economic levels, the impact is beginning to be felt in the areas of energy efficiency and conservation and reduction of pollution. The main elements of the reform include coal price liberalization, increase of industrial energy prices towards economic levels, and gradual increases of household energy prices first to the level paid by industrial consumers and then to levels reflecting economic costs. After major price adjustments of all network fuels through January 1, 1992, the Government slowed down the pace of energy price increases. However, the system of approximately quarterly price adjustments is expected to result in modest real price increases over the medium term. Network fuel prices, though still being controlled, are now on average at about 60% of their estimated economic levels, with individual fuels ranging from 50-100% depending on tariff categories. Network fuel tariff studies have been completed under terms of reference and with consultants satisfactory to the Bank and could provide the Government with guidance for the economic pricing of network fuels. 13. Coal prices ex mine, now being set virtually freely by the market, have almost reached import parity levels (adjusted for quality) following major price increases during the last quarter of 1993. In addition, coal mine operating subsidies have been eliminated, except for those mines that are being closed down. Coal export controls have been suspended. As of September 1, 1994, electricity prices for industry and households were at about 61% and 51% of their estimated economic levels, respectively. The average residential price is about 138% of the average industrial price (less than 50% in early 1990). The average gas price for industry is now at 100% of its economic level. The gas price for households is at 61% of its economic level; it is now at about 140% of the price for industry (16% in early 1990). District heating contract prices have moved to about 63% of their economic level and the Government reduced subsidies to households from 78% in 1991 to about 10% as of January 1, 1995. These subsidies have already been eliminated in many major cities and are expected to be eliminated in most of the country by the end of 1996. 14. Given that the SECAL's pricing conditionality was met, the Bank and the Government started a policy dialogue on how to proceed with price adjustment from
 here on to ensure that energy prices would reach economic levels. A key factor in the Government's decision-making process about energy pricing should be the fact that most of the resources for the energy sector's huge investment needs would have to be generated domestically. Given the scarcity of budget funds, as well as for reasons of economic efficiency, these would have to come from the sector's internal cash flow and from borrowing. Foreign direct investment also has a vital role to play, but such capital, as well as internal and external borrowings, will only be forthcoming if there is a transparent regulatory framework and if energy prices are allowed to fully reflect economic costs. d. Energy Regulatory Framework 15. The Government has prepared a draft energy law for presentation to the Parliament. This law would set up the future energy regulatory framework and establish the Energy Regulatory Agency. As it stands, the draft provides for competition in the network fuel subsectors and for open access to new entrants. The Energy Regulatory Agency would have adequate autonomy, subject to overall accountability to the Council of Ministers. The draft law is expected to be submitted to Parliament in the Fall of 1995. The Bank/ESMAP will cooperate with the drafting of secondary legislation, permits, licenses, statutes and training of personnel for the future Energy Regulatory Agency. C. Power Sector a. Organization 16. The power sector underwent substantial demonopolization and divestiture. Until September 1990 it consisted of 106 enterprises combined in the Power and Lignite Board. Upon dissolution of the Power and Lignite Board, all service enterprises were spun off into joint stock companies. The sector now consists of 68 autonomous enterprises specialized in the generation, transmission and distribution of electricity. There are 34 thermal power and combined heat and power generating enterprises; 33 distribution enterprises, who also own 113 small hydro plants and one pumped storage plant; and one transmission company (PPGC) which also owns four pumped storage plants. 17. Electricity dispatching is done by PPGC, which is moving towards a merit order dispatching system. It has set separate capacity and energy charges and has curtailed its power purchases from more expensive generators. These are vital steps towards a new system, with major implications for both efficient as well as inefficient producers. Equally importantly, power purchase agreements are now being introduced. These elements constitute the corner stones of an open and competitive power sector (para. 33). 18. Through its national dispatch center and five regional dispatch centers, PPGC maintains optimum electricity supply and transmission efficiency and reliability, and manages international power exchanges and transits (para 46).
 -6- b. Generation 19. As of the end of 1993, the Polish power sector had an installed capacity of 32,750 MW0; 90% of this belongs to the power industry and 10% to industrial auto-producers. The power industry generates most of its electricity through thermal power plants (condensing units: 22,078 MW9, combined heat and power units: 5,353 MW.) and the remaining 2,007 MWe through hydropower plants. In addition to electricity generation, the power industry supplies heat to district heating networks in fifty major cities. Its total available thermal capacity is about 26,940 MWt, of which 11,435 MWt in CHP units and 15,505 MWt in large HOBs. On average, CHP plants account for 66% of the power sector's total heat production, but for only 10% of total electricity generation. Thus, while CHP is crucial to heat supply, it constitutes still a relatively small portion of electric power production. This situation should be reversed over time, since increased use of CHP is energy efficient, relatively non-polluting, and increases heat network dispatchability. 20. Generating capacity is designed primarily for burning hard coal (66%) and lignite (28%), while the remaining 6% is provided by hydro plants. About 39% of the energy generated by the sector is produced by lignite-fired plant, 52% by coal-fired plant, 3% by hydro plant and 6% by individual autoproducers. However, up to half of the electricity currently purchased by PPGC during peak season is produced by the large lignite generators. Implementation of the power tariff study's recommendations should ensure that the true costs of lignite and its environmental impact are adequately reflected. Coal-fired thermal power plant are designed to operate under base load rather than cyclical conditions. They have the ability to turn down to approximately 80% of rated output. However, because of the mix of generating plant within the system, i.e., CHP operating as base load during the winter and not subject to merit order dispatch, together with very limited peaking capacity comprising principally pumped storage plants, the thermal generating units are obliged to operate under a reduced two shift operation mode or be completely shut down, especially during the low demand period in summer. This situation should change over time, as older base load capacity is retired and as operationally more flexible power plants are introduced. The latter could be either through the use of gas turbines for peaking or through thermal generating plants with the ability to turn down to 40% of rated output. However, increased use of CHP will remain necessary for more cost-effective and efficient heat generation compared to using polluting and inefficient local heat-only-boilers. 21. The Polish power system has many units which have passed their design life. By 1998, when new emission standards go into effect, 17% of capacity will have an average age of about 35 years; 47% of capacity will be about 29 years old. Poor instrumentation and automation control and the use of high ash coal are other factors contributing to a low average plant availability of 75-85%, compared to 85-90% for Western Europe (including scheduled maintenance). Poland has currently no nuclear generating capacity and none is planned. c. Transmission and Distribution 22. The Polish high voltage transmission grid comprises four voltage levels: 750, 400, 220 and 110 kV. The 750 kV line was completed in 1984, the 400 kV
 - 7 - system in 1964 and the 220 kV system in 1952. The 110 kV system is much older and is in some areas in significant need of rehabilitation. Most CHP plants are integrated into the 110 kV network. The 110 kV network currently operates on an interconnected basis throughout the country with the exception of the Katowice area, where it is sectionalized in order to limit fault levels. Most of the large generators (200 MW unit rating) are connected to the 220 kV network, which represents a partial overlay of the existing 110 kV system. The 400 kV system originally played a limited role. When established its principal function was power wheeling, particularly from the Ukraine to the Czech Republic, and power exchange with the former East Germany. During recent years the 400 kV system was further developed to permit bulk power transfer within the country. However, neither the 400 kV nor the 220 kV systems adequately offload the 110 kV system. This results in significant losses in the 110 kV system as it must fulfill the dual roles of subtransmission and distribution system. 23. Medium and low voltage networks are poorly designed and obsolete in some places, lack connecting and safety devices, and need major rehabilitation. Transmission and distribution losses in Poland average over 14%, compared to 7-8% in Western European countries of comparable size. About 85% of these losses are in distribution networks. PPGC's proposed investment program, of which the proposed project is an integral part, would offload the underlying networks and transport power on a much more efficient basis, resulting in a reduction in power losses of about 120 GWh/year. 24. Various studies were undertaken to determine the optimal sequencing for transmission system investments: (a) a UCPTE study, which provides an assessment of the transmission modernization and reinforcement required to permit interconnection with Western Europe; and (b) a long-term power system development study (para. 68), which defines network configuration to the year 2010. Both studies identified transmission projects needed in the immediate future that both meet the long-term development needs of the system and that satisfy the requirements of UCPTE and which are typical of requirements that any power system should meet to have secure and efficient system operations. These projects are part of PPGC's proposed investment program. More detail on the power sector and the current network condition is provided in Annexes 2-2 and 2-3. d. Power Demand 25. Electricity demand increased at 2.2% per annum during 1980-88 and peaked at 149 TWh in 1988. Since then it decreased to 131 TWh in 1993. The gross reserve margin of the system is about 25-30%, typical for a thermal system. However, since the winter peaks are pronounced in Poland, during the remainder of the year the margins may go up to 40-50%. 26. The future demand for electricity depends not only on economic growth but also on the combined effects of structural changes in the economy and measures to enhance energy conservation and efficiency. The complexity of the transition towards a market economy, the uncertainty about the pace of implementation of structural reform and the impact of continuous energy price adjustments have made the preparation of a reliable medium term electricity demand forecast very difficult.
 27. Since 1991, various Polish and foreign agencies have carried out electricity demand forecasts using different methods. For example, demand forecasts prepared by the Paris-based International Energy Agency and the Polish Ministry of Industry and Trade were carried out by following mainly the traditional income elasticity approach, while other demand forecasts by Polish research institutes were prepared with additional technical, microeconomic and population variables as determinants. Despite the differences in focus and methods, these forecasts generally agree on the trend of the future electricity demand. Most predict slightly decreasing demand through 1994 and gradually increasing demand thereafter. 28. In addition to the above PPGC, in cooperation with foreign consultants, recently also prepared a demand forecast using the current assessment of macroeconomic developments. Three scenarios of electricity demand, based on alternative GDP growth scenarios (high, medium and low growth), were used. The low GDP growth scenario was chosen as the base case both for the least cost investment plan (para. 68) as well as for the power tariff study (para. 58). It estimates that electricity demand through 1994 would remain at the 1990 level, and that demand between 1995 and 2000 would grow at approximately 2.5% per annum. This appears realistic, in view of the Bank's own assumption of an annual GDP growth rate of about 5% starting in 1995 and consumer elasticity of demand in response to further price increases. Therefore, this scenario has also been retained for the financial and economic calculations in this report. e. Power Sector Restructuring 29. Mergers. Conform the Government's 1991 letter of sector development policy, the existing 34 generating enterprises would be regrouped into a smaller number of joint stock companies. The merger criteria would be competitiveness and financial viability. The hard coal-fired generating plants would be grouped into a maximum of four companies (representing about 4,000 MW each). The lignite-fired power plants and their adjacent lignite mines would be combined into three generating companies. The lignite-fired plants would have capacities of 4300 MW, 2500 MW and 2000 MW, respectively. Additionally, there would be 19 CHP companies. 30. The number of distribution companies would remain at the present 33. Six of these would serve a minimum of 150,000 consumers, and 27 would serve more than 200,000 customers each. It was felt that the current size of the distribution companies was appropriate and that the benefits of mergers would be far outweighed by the costs, including loss of contact with customers. In addition, the current bulk tariff structure for distributors virtually ensures that prices for end-users would probably not vary by more than 20% throughout the country. 31. Energy Law and Regulatory Framework.  - 29 - PART VI - BENEFITS OF THE PROJECT A. Project Benefits 104. The focus of the economic analysis is on the entire investment program of PPGC. This is mainly because the benefits associated with the investment components under the project cannot be quantitatively measured in isolation from other components of the program, unless arbitrary assumptions on allocating the benefits to each component are made. The internal economic rate of return (ERR) is, therefore, calculated on the basis of the incremental benefit and cost streams connected with the 1995-2001 investment program, of which the Bank project is an integral part. It covers the program's highest priority components and is crucial for undertaking the remainder of the program. Details on the ERR calculation are provided in Annex 6-1. 105. Benefits. The economic benefits associated with the entire investment program can be summarized as follows: (a) enhanced reliability of the transmission system; (b) reduced transmission losses and operation and maintenance costs; (c) increased income from power wheeling and exports; and (d) reduced environmental pollution. For the purpose of the ERR calculation, PPGC's incremental transmission revenue is used as a proxy for the economic benefits of its investment program and operations. 106. Incremental transmission revenues were based on the difference between revenues with and without the program and were valued using transmission revenue and net export revenue. With the program, PPGC would be able to have firm power contracts for domestic sales and exports to Austria and the Czech Republic and maintain power exports to Germany. Without the program, a portion of PPGC's domestic and export contracts would be on an interruptible basis and at 50% of the price of firm contracts; exports to Germany would cease, resulting in lost revenues for the company. Other quantifiable benefits made possible by implementing the program comprise: (i) a reduction in ordered capacity by about 2% of annual peak demand per year (or 540 MW./year) valued at the marginal cost of generation capacity of US$53/kW/year; (ii) a reduction in incremental operating and maintenance (O&M) costs estimated at 2% of the value of the existing assets annually; and (iii) savings equivalent to about US$14 million per year due to transmission system reinforcement resulting in reduced unsupplied demand (during the winter period mainly), a better use of merit-order dispatching resulting in lower generation costs, and reduced transmission losses. 107. Costs. The costs associated with PPGC's investment program and used for the ERR calculation comprise: (i) the total costs of the investment program over the period 1995-2001, excluding price contingencies, custom duties and taxes, and interest during construction; and (ii) the corresponding annual incremental O&M costs, estimated at 2% of the cumulative capital investment costs. Other costs such as incremental overhead costs for implementing the program were assumed to be offset by the reduction in manpower requirements at the substation level resulting from the improved telecommunication and telecontrol of substations. Estimates of the local and foreign costs are in March 1994 prices. Local costs are either directly costed in international prices or are converted to US dollars using the average 1994 exchange rate.

The internal economic rate of return, based on the benefit and cost streams discussed above, is estimated at 21%, which is above the 12% discount rate generally applied to Poland. A sensitivity analysis was carried out to test the robustness of the ERR. The ERR would go down to 12% if investment costs were to increase by 50%, or if all quantifiable benefits were to decrease by 40%. A combination of 20% higher investments costs and 25% lower benefits would decrease the ERR to 12%. The ERR is also affected, to a lesser degree, by changes in the price for interruptible contracts: if this price increases from 50% to 90% of the price for firm contracts, the ERR would go down to 12%. Such a delay could negatively affect PPGC's internal cash flow, needed for further system improvements. Furthermore, the project's cash flow is based on the conservative assumption of zero price increases in real terms over the medium term. The Polish economy, which contracted sharply in 1990-91 after the Economic Transformation Program was launched in January 1990, shows signs of recovering. After a 12 % decline in 1990 and an 8 % decline in 1991, GDP registered an increase of 1.5% in 1992 and 3.8% in 1993, the most recent year for which complete data are available. Among the important structural changes which have taken place, the dominance of heavy industries has declined and light industries have steadily increased in importance. These macroeconomic and structural changes have had a major impact on the energy sector. Industrial energy consumption experienced the largest decline (15% in 1990, 12% in 1991 and 8% in 1992), due to the significant decrease in industrial output and the closure or downsizing of several major energy-intensive enterprises, and a modest 1% growth in 1993. Residential energy consumption also declined because of the decrease of real household incomes combined with large increases in residential energy prices. The level of residential energy consumption in 1993 was 3% higher than in 1992 but still 11% lower than in 1989. Consequently, Poland's total energy consumption decreased by almost 20% in 1990 and by about 3% in 1991, and gradually increased by about 1% per year during 1992-93. 2. Declining Production. Poland produces on average 97% of its total energy needs. Hard coal, lignite and natural gas are the main energy sources produced in Poland. Since 1990, their production experienced large declines due to Poland's industrial restructuring and decline in industry demand. Hard Coal and lignite: Continuing the downward trend started in 1989 when coal mines produced a total of 111 million TOE, production decreased by about 17 million TOE (a 15% drop) in 1990, by about 4 million TOE in 1991 (a 4% drop), by about 2 million TOE in 1992 (a 2% drop), and reached 89 million TOE in 1993. With an annual hard coal output of 76 million TOE (134 million tons) Poland is now ranked as the world's seventh largest hard coal producer rather than the fourth as it had been for many years until 1989. Natural Gas: Domestic production of natural gas varies according to the seasonal variations in gas demand, with contracted gas imports (exclusively from the Former Soviet Union (FSU)) providing the base supply. In 1990 production declined by about 1 million TOE, a 31% decline from the 1989 level of 3.5 million TOE. Though it bounced back by about 12% to reach a level of 2.7 million TOE in 1991, production in 1992, at a level of 2.6 million TOE, was at only about 75% of the 1989 production level. Because of additional gas supply requirements to meet growing demand from residential customers combined with a decrease in gas imports, domestic production increased in 1993 by 28% to a level of 3.3 million TOE, corresponding to 95% of the 1989 production level. 3. Changes in Energy Trade. Net imports account on average for 3% of Poland's total energy needs. While imports typically provide nearly 100% of oil supplies and 60-75% of gas supplies, exports consist mainly of hard coal. Because of factor such as export quotas, the abrupt decline in exports to the FSU, and the
 Annex 2-1 Page 2 of 4 continuous production declines, hard coal exports dropped sharply from the 1989 level (19.4 million TOE) and were in 1991 about 74% of the 1989 export level. Starting in 1992, Poland diversified its export market and gradually increased its coal exports again, to reach in 1993 about 85% of the 1989 export level. On the import side, Poland imported 14.1 million TOE of crude oil in 1993, 5% less than the 1989 level. More than half of the crude oil imports came from the FSU. Natural gas imports from the FSU decreased in 1991 by about 1.5 million TOE from the 1990 level (a 21% decline). Gas imports in 1992 stayed at the 1991 level and decreased by 12% in 1993. Energy trade is now almost exclusively conducted in hard currencies. In monetary terms, total energy imports in 1993 were US$2.3 billion, equal to 12% of total goods imports. Total energy exports were US$1.4 billion, equal to about 10% of total goods exports. 4. Declining Role of Coal and Increasing Role of Gas, Oil and District Heat. As the structure of the Polish economy changes and energy prices are being adjusted towards economic levels, Poland's energy consumption is moving away from coal towards natural gas and oil. Tighter enforcement of environmental standards will accelerate this change. Though the share of coal (hard coal and lignite) in primary energy supply has been stable at about 93% during 1989-93, the share of coal in final energy consumption has declined significantly, from 41% in 1989 to 36% in 1993. During the same period, the combined share of oil and gas in final energy consumption increased from 27% to 29% and the share of district heat increased from 21% to 24%. The drop of coal's share in final consumption reflects in part the changes in the structure of industrial production, because industrial sectors with high coal consumption experienced the sharpest contraction during this period. Another factor is the increasingly higher environmental user charges and penalties, which induce a fuel switching away from coal. Even though domestic supplies of both oil and gas will in the short-term remain low compared to the potential demand, domestic gas production could supply in the medium-term a larger part of demand if Poland's reserves of natural gas and coal-bed methane are tapped more efficiently.

Age of the Units. The Polish power system suffers from aging units, most of which have passed their design life. Out of the 255 turbosets, 89 units with a total capacity of 2,831 MWe (or 10% of the installed electric capacity) have been in service for over 30 years; 69 units (or 7,349 MW0 or 27% of total installed electric capacity) are over 20 years old. By introducing proper pricing for bulk heat between the power utility and the DHEs and enforcing environmental regulations for heavily polluting local HOBs, CHP's contribution in both power and heat production should be increased. In addition, a strategy towards converting either existing condensing plants and/or coal burning HOBs to a CHP mode of operation should be developed, wherever natural gas fired CHPs/HOBs are not a viable option. The 400 kV transmission grid was build during the 1970s and '80s. Although quite modern in concept, it is still not a fully integrated system. Hence, reliability of electricity supply in case of plant failure is low. The 220 kV grid was built in the 1950s and '60s, and is fully utilized. Some areas in the Upper Silesia are overloaded, thus increasing energy losses. Networks at 110 kV voltage and lower are of poor design and obsolete technologies, lack connecting and safety devices, and are in need of major rehabilitation. During 1990-93, system gross reserve margin varied within the 25-33% range, typical for a thermal system. The balance is for agriculture and street lighting, which has remained stable at about 9% of total consumption. 21. System Load Factor. Until 1989, the system load factor was on average about 69%. This is typical for a system with a flat load curve and confirms that the Polish system is energy intensive. The load factor decreased to about 66% during 1990-91, increased to about 70% in 1992 and decreased again to 66% in 1993. The decrease in 1990-91 and in 1993 can be explained partially by the energy restructuring program and consumer awareness due to increases in energy prices. The 1992 increase in the load factor can probably be explained by the fact that consumers have become accustomed to the new electricity price levels. The load factor is an important factor to consider in planning energy strategy for the future. A high load factor is significant in several respects: (i) efficiency measures must be effective over a period of many hours in order to have a significant impact; (ii) it makes it more difficult to schedule planned maintenance, especially when long lasting reliability problems appear; and (iii) it makes pollution problems more severe and increases the need for pollution controls. 22. This period of relatively low electricity demand combined with the current excess capacity provides an ideal opportunity for: (a) implementing a more aggressive plant retirement, rehabilitation and modernization program; (b) making provision for installing additional peaking plants (e.g., relatively cheap and quick to install gas turbines), if demand growth should materialize, thus deferring any major capital intensive baseload plants beyond 2000; (c) defining an implementation strategy for improving the environmental performance of thermal power plants to the extent possible to meet new emission standards on a least- cost basis; (d) strengthening the transmission grid, and increasing its transfer capacity and reliability through automation and loop closing; and (e) reducing transmission and distribution energy losses through flow switching from the presently overloaded 110 kV grid to higher voltage carriers.

The worst situation is at the 110 kV level, where much of the primary equipment is totally obsolete, at least 40 years old in design and service life, and requires frequent attention to maintain a barely acceptable level of mechanical performance. There is a mixture of airblast and minimum oil circuit breaker types, none of which are likely to be capable of performing their assigned rating and cannot be assigned any useful fault current interruption rating. Spare parts are virtually unavailable, which represents a major problem. Current Condition of the Network's Secondary Apparatus 6. The secondary equipment utilized in both the 220 and 110 kV substations, comprising the protection, control and telecommunications systems, provides an inadequate performance from the point of view of both security and dependability. Transmission lines require duplicate main protection, but the existing scheme comprises only a single main protection with supplementary ground relaying. In many instances fault clearing times are quite long, resulting in poor network performance. In a number of instances busbar zone protection is not provided, which may cause widespread shutdown of the 220 kV network in case of a busbar fault. The secondary equipment needs to be upgraded to achieve more secure protection clearing times in order to meet the performance criteria of the Polish power grid, whether interconnected with UCPTE or operating in isolation. Redundancy of protective relaying, together with design diversity is necessary to achieve these objectives, particularly in the case of transmission line protection. The same level of redundancy and security will need to be applied to the auxiliary power systems supplying the relaying schemes to achieve the necessary duplication of the AC and DC auxiliary power systems. At large substations at key points within the transmission system, emergency diesel generators will be needed to permit the restoration of power supply to the substation in the event of a total power system blackout. Work Required at 400/220/110 kV Levels 9. The work required across the 400/220/110 kV interconnected system may be classified as follows: (a) modernization in accordance with UCPTE criteria, e.g. decrease of fault clearing time, faster circuit breakers and protection relays, and higher security relaying systems to ensure fault detection. This is typically required for 400 kV equipment in substations that are essential to the UCPTE interconnection; (b) refurbishment as required by increase in network load, e.g. fault levels and changes of the circuit breakers. This is typically required for the 220 kV equipment in substations that are essential to both the Polish power network and the UCPTE interconnection; (c) replacement of inadequate equipment as indicated by poor performance, high failure rate, lack of spare parts, high maintenance costs, obsolete equipment and design limitations. This is typically required for 220 and 110 kV substations using the old Russian type of equipment; and (d) replacement of equipment likely to fail (explode) and that could endanger the safety of operating staff and of the public where stations are close to public areas. This is typically required for the 110 kV equipment substations. 10. A comprehensive survey has been completed by PPGC that identifies all 400 and 220 kV primary equipment in need of replacement. A priority schedule was established for replacement of 400 and 220 kV equipment in substations located in the western part of Poland (adjacent to the borders). These substations are critical both to the Polish power network and the UCPTE interconnection. A program for rehabilitating the other 400 and 220 kV substation equipment will be implemented after completion of this project. While this schedule also includes replacement of 110 kV substation equipment in conjunction with 400 and 220 kV equipment, a major separate replacement program will also be required for all other 110 kV equipment, which is the responsibility of the distribution companies. This should be developed in conjunction with the relegation of this network to a normal power distribution function (as opposed to a subtransmission function). In other words, the 110 kV equipment substations should be replaced only if they are an integral part of a long-term distribution system development plan.

The plants are being operated and maintained by four separate joint stock companies, owned by the employees who got a part of the share capital of the pumped storage power plants themselves. Transfer Pricing Structure a. Between Generation and Transmission 9. The transfer price between generation and transmission is composed of a fixed charge, representing the capacity payment, and a variable charge, representing fuel and other variable expenses. 10. Fixed Payment Calculation. Capacity for any generating plant, can be specified in 5 different ways: i) Standard Capacity (SC): the average annual achieved capacity of the generating plant during the last 3 years; ii) Declared Capacity (DC): the capacity the generating plant desires to sell, calculated by subtracting the planned and expected forced outages from the standard capacity; iii) Ordered Capacity (OC): the capacity PPGC plans to buy; iv) Non-Ordered Capacity (NC): the capacity declared but not bought; and v) Realized Capacity (RC): the capacity actually sold to PPGC. The following always holds: SC => DC => OC => RC, and SC -> OC + NC. 11. Each year, on the basis of projected demand and a reserve margin, the Ministry of Industry and Trade prepares an annual capacity balance. The capacity is then allocated to generators, according to the average cost of production in generating plants, starting with the least cost producer such as the base load plants. For these low cost producers, DC is equal to OC; for high cost producers, OC is less than DC, or OC is equal to zero. The fixed payment for
 Annex 3-3 Page 5 of 5 each generating plant is determined based on the standard capacity, but with higher payment to ordered capacity and lower payment to non-ordered capacity. 12. Realized capacity may be less than ordered capacity due to a variety of reasons. If it is due to lack of demand, the total ordered capacity is paid. If it is due to plant failure, the plant has to compensate PPGC for the undelivered capacity. 13. The payment to each unit of capacity is composed of: depreciation, debt service, repair and maintenance cost (overhead) and the allowed return to fixed assets in generating plants. The levels of depreciation and debt service vary among generating plants, so they are determined on the basis of each individual plant. However, the repair and maintenance cost is determined by the averages for different types of generators of all generating plants. Altogether there are 8 types of different generators grouped according to capacity, fuel requirements, and mode of generation (power only or CHP), and each of them has a different cost structure. The allowed return on fixed assets, which may vary from time to time and is defined as the rate of return on the book value of the fixed assets, is uniform across generation, transmission and distribution subsectors. However, only a portion (65% in 1994) of this allowed return on the fixed assets is included in the fixed payment; the remaining 35% is part of the variable payment. By transferring a portion of the return on assets to the variable payment, those generators which sell more electricity to PPGC receive higher payment for their fixed assets. 14. Variable Payment Calculation. The variable payment to each unit of energy delivered is the sum of the following cost items: fuel, transportation, environment fee and a portion of the return on fixed assets. The cost of fuel is calculated on the basis of the calorific value of the standard fuel (hard coal) for all plants; the transportation cost is calculated on a standard rate per unit of standard fuel for all plants; and the environment user charges are calculated based on the emission levels of standard fuel and the actual environmental fee. For CHP plants of capacity less than 100 MWe, the payment is an aggregate unit kWh charge, comprising fixed and variable costs, calculated on the basis of prices set for collector power plants. b. Between Transmission and Distribution 15. The transfer price between PPGC and the distribution companies is determined individually, taking into account the following cost items of the distribution company: depreciation, debt service, repair and maintenance costs, the rate of return on fixed assets and distribution losses. The repair and maintenance cost is an average for all distribution companies. Other costs are also individually dependent on each distribution company.

The work will be scheduled to be coordinated with planned outages in connection with the modernization of the Turow plant. 19. Alternative Technology Option - Gas Insulated Switchgear. Extensive civil and engineering work is required at Mikulowa. Based on the present design and modernization plans, it is estimated that four and a half years would be required to complete the total upgrading at Mikulowa. Using gas insulated switchgear (GIS) technology for the total substation or for a part of the substation would permit minimizing the outage requirements and shorten the construction period. The use of GIS technology would provide an opportunity to purchase 400, 220 and 110 kV switchgear on an individual turnkey basis, with a well defined scope of work and minimal economic risk, as the complete station can be constructed and commissioned without the need for significant outages other than those required for termination circuits. The overall construction schedule would be significantly reduced as construction work can proceed without impediment. While the capital cost may be higher than the design currently developed, it may well be an economically more viable solution when compared to the turnkey solution for the modernization based on the design currently developed. A partial solution that uses GIS at only one voltage level, e.g. 110 kV, may be also appropriate. A definitive project schedule will be developed when a specific contract strategy, defined mostly by the modernization technology considered, has been

Provision was made in the project cost estimates for the possibility to use GIS technology at Mikulowa, should this option be economically viable. 220 kV Une Modernization Program 20. PPGC carried out a detailed investigation of the condition of the 220 kV transmission lines and identified the degree of modernization, upgrading and refurbishment required in order to restore them to a state that would provide a further 30-35 years of service. The remedial work may be classified into the following groups: (i) the transmission line towers, foundations, and insulating structures are in poor condition so that the security of the line is jeopardized; (ii) the cross section of the phase conductors is inadequate for the current rating required by the present power transfer needs of the system, or the existing conductor has corroded and is in need of replacement; (iii) the existing ground wires are corroded and unsuitable for further service and in addition, do not have the capacity to withstand circuit faults; and (iv) the modernization of the telecommunications system throughout the Polish power network is essential and can be combined with the replacement of the ground wires through the installation of a fiber optic ground wire cable. Bank-Financed Equipment 21. The Bank-financed equipment items will be procured in accordance with Bank's procurement procedures. For the substations, and for different voltage levels (400, 220 and 110 kV), the list of equipment comprises: (i) power transformers; (ii) switchyard equipment consisting of circuit breakers, disconnectors and related operating mechanisms, earthing switching systems, current transformers, voltage transformers, surge arresters, secondary circuits for bays and transformers, busbar and failure protection systems; (iii) 110 kV cables; (iv) auxiliary equipment; (v) shunt reactors; and (vi) telecommunication and telecontrol equipment. For the lines, the list of equipment consists of towers, insulators (long rod unit type for the lines to be modernized), conductors, ground wires, fiber optic ground wires and repeater stations. The equipment quantities and the procurement arrangements are presented in Annex 4-3. Technical Assistance 22. The proposed project would also finance technical assistance and training for PPGC staff as required. An amount of about US$3.3 million has been incorporated into the loan amount for this purpose. Training needs are expected to be more pronounced in the management and commercial areas (corporate financial planning and management, budgeting, accounting, project economics, contracting and international trade, marketing and consumer services, and human resource management) than in the strictly technical area. However, a certain amount of training for the technical staff will de facto be provided by the suppliers of equipment and goods to be procured under the project. The technical assistance program is entirely flexible, to permit reorientation towards high priority areas that may emerge during project implementation.

 Annex 6-1 Page 1 of 3 POLAND - POWER TRANSMISSION PROJECT Economic Analysis 1. The focus of the economic analysis is on the entire investment program of PPGC, of which the proposed project is an integral part. This is mainly because the benefits associated with the investment components under the project cannot be quantitatively measured in isolation from other components of the program, unless arbitrary assumptions on allocating the benefits to each component are made. The internal economic rate of return (ERR) is, therefore, calculated on the basis of the incremental benefit and cost streams connected with the 1995- 2001 time-slice of the total investment program. The Bank project covers the highest priority components in this program and is crucial for the undertaking of the remaining part of the program. Economic Benefits 2. Qualitative Analysis. The economic benefits associated with the entire investment program can be summarized, inter alia, in the following qualitative terms: a. Enhanced reliability of the transmission system: the reinforcement and rehabilitation of existing transmission lines and substations, especially at the 220 kV and 110 kV level, and functional reconfiguration of all high voltage lines and substations included in the program will improve the reliability of the transmission system and reduce network outages and the cost to the Polish economy of energy not served. The reliability of electricity supply is vital for electricity-dependent industries (such as high technology and chemical industries). Unless the reliability is up to a basic standard these industries will have to invest in expensive standby power generation facilities to guarantee their continuous production. Additionally, compared to neighboring/competing countries, a more reliable electricity supply is also a factor that could induce foreign investment in industries in Poland; b. Reduced transmission losses and operation and maintenance costs: compared to modern Western transmission systems, the Polish system experiences much higher transmission losses and operation and maintenance costs. Its obsolete equipment is very inefficient and frequent maintenance is needed to keep it performing at an acceptable level. The proposed investment program will greatly increase the efficiency of the overall network performance through replacement, upgrading and rehabilitation of power transmission equipment, improved power system dispatch and better maintenance scheduling; c. Deferred and reduced investments in transmission and generation capacity and reserve margins due to increased capacity of rehabilitated system components: the implementation of the proposed investment program will increase the transfer capacity of the
 Annex 6-1 Page 2 of 3 transmission network and thus reduce or defer transmission investments. The investment program can also reduce or defer investment in generation capacity through a reduced need for spinning reserve and standby capacity. This would result from the installation of modern telecommunication and control equipment and reduced peaking capacity and reserve margins through proposed interconnection with UCPTE; d. Increased income from Dower wheeling and exports: the proposed interconnections with UCPTE and neighboring countries provide the necessary basis for Poland to be actively involved in electricity trade in Europe, thus generating more income for the economy. The upgrade to UCPTE standards under the program would permit to maintain the power exports to Germany; and e. Reduced environmental pollution: investments in transmission network optimization will make it possible to supply power from the most efficient coal-fired generation units rather than the less efficient ones. This improved dispatching will decrease overall coal combustion while generating the same amount of electricity, and thus reduce air pollution. The proposed investments would also permit the modernization and environmental upgrade of highly polluting power plants without interruption of power supply. The introduction of environmental dispatching, which can be achieved by the installation of telecommunication and control equipment as proposed in the program, would further reduce environmental pollution. 3. Quantitative Analysis. For the purpose of the ERR calculation, PPGC's incremental transmission revenue is used as a proxy for the quantifiable economic benefits of its investment program and operations. It is an estimate of the consumer's willingness to pay. Transmission revenue is regarded only as the minimum measure of the actual benefits, since this revenue reflects only a portion of the total benefits of PPGC's investment program. In particular, this revenue-based measurement does not capture the incremental consumer surplus. The ERR calculation, including cost and benefit streams and assumptions, is shown in Table 6.1. An explanation of the ERR calculation with reference to the benefit items listed in Table 6.1 is provided in paras. 4-5. 4. Incremental transmission revenues were based on the difference between revenues with and without the program. With the program, PPGC would be able to ensure firm power contracts for exports to Austria and Czech Republic (item 5.1 of Table 6.1) and domestic sales (items 5.2 and 5.3 of Table 6.1) and maintain power exports to Germany (item 9 of Table 6.1). Without the program, a portion of PPGC's domestic sales and export contracts would be supplied on an interruptible basis and at lower contract price, and the entire exports to Germany would cease, resulting in lost revenues for the company. Interruptible contracts valued at about 50% of prices for firm contracts would affect about 30% of 1995 domestic sales, the entire incremental domestic sales (in excess of the base year 1995 demand) and the entire exports to Austria and Czech Republic. Incremental revenues from domestic sales and exports were valued using a transmission revenue of about US$14/MWh and a net export revenue of about US$84/MWh.
 Annex 6-1 Page 3 of 3 5. Other quantifiable benefits made possible by implementing the program comprise: (i) reduction in ordered capacity for spinning reserves and standby capacity by about 2% of annual peak demand per year (or 540 MW./year) valued at marginal cost of generation capacity of US$53/kW-year (item 6 of Table 6.1); (ii) reduction in incremental operating and maintenance (O&M) costs estimated as 2% of the value of the existing assets annually (item 8 of Table 6.1); and (iii) savings equivalent to about US$ 14 million per year due to transmission system reinforcement and covering reduced unsupplied demand (during the winter period mainly), a better use of merit-order dispatch resulting in lower generation costs, and reduced transmission losses (item 7 of Table 6.1). Savings from system reinforcement were estimated from the results of the load flow analysis and the probabilistic simulation of supply reliability with and without the reinforcement. Economic Costs 6. The costs associated with PPGC's investment program and used for the ERR calculation comprise: (i) the total costs of the investment program over the period 1995-2001, excluding price contingencies, custom duties and taxes, and interests during construction (item 2 of Table 6.1); and (ii) the corresponding annual incremental O&M costs, estimated as 2% of the cumulative capital investment costs (item 3 of Table 6.1). Other costs such as incremental overhead costs for implementing the program were assumed to be offset by the reduction in manpower requirements at substation level resulting from the improved telecommunication and telecontrol of substations. Estimates of the local and foreign costs are in March 1994 prices. Local costs are either directly costed in international prices or are converted to US dollars using the average 1994 exchange rate. Economic Rate of Return 7. The program yields an economic rate of return of 21%. The ERR reflects the implementation of the program during 1995-2001. Benefits from exports to Germany are achieved only upon implementing the entire program and remain constant thereafter for 15 years (the assumed economic useful life of the investment). Other program benefits and incremental costs build up in proportion to the progress of program implementation, from 8% in 1995 to the full value in 2001, and remain constant thereafter for 15 years (item 1 of Table 6.1). Transmission revenue and net export revenue in 1995 were kept constant in real terms. Sensitivity Analysis 8. The internal economic rate of return, based on the benefit and cost streams discussed above, is estimated at 21%, which is above the 12% discount rate generally applied to Poland. A sensitivity analysis was carried out to test the robustness of the ERR. The ERR would go down to 12% if investment costs were to increase by 50%, or if all quantifiable benefits were to decrease by 40%. A combination of 20% higher investments costs and 25% lower benefits would decrease the ERR to 12%. The ERR is also affected, to a lesser degree, by changes in the price for interruptible contracts: if this price increases from 50% to 90% of the price for firm contracts, the ERR would go down to 12%.

doc.abstracts: The Power Transmission Project's objectives are to: 1) improve the reliability of the existing high voltage grid through rehabilitation and reinforcement; 2) enhance security of power supply in Poland by interconnecting the Polish power grid with that of Western Europe, thus improving Poland's power trade and wheeling capability; 3) improve the network's operational performance and control through transmission and loss reduction and improved dispatching, thereby enhancing energy conservation and efficiency; 4) reduce environmental pollution; and 5) enhance the Polish Power Grid Company's (PPGC) institutional capabilities. The project comprises the following major components: 1) substation modernization program, consisting of the modernization of strategic substations in the Western and Central-Western regions of Poland to meet the design performance levels required for the system reliability and international interconnections and shunt reactive compensation at specific substations to ensure steady voltage control; 2) the 220 kilovolt line modernization program; and 3) technical assistance to PPGC.
